Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: Enabling Real-Time Detection and Identification of Friction Stir Welding Defects Through the Use of Physics-Based Process Dynamic Modeling

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Grant Opportunities for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) award provides funding for the investigation and development of a real-time defect detection approach for the material joining process known as friction stir welding. The defect detection approach will use physics-based process and defect dynamic modeling to filter or condition real-time process measurements to significantly improve the reliability of detection. The research project will develop and validate the physics-based process and defect disturbance models through a combination of process-level system identification, using both computational and experimental data, and system level validation, including verification of real-time in-situ defect detection capabilities. The project will investigate the limitations and applicability of the overall defect detection approach to include the evaluation of the sensitivity to variations in defect size and defect type and the evaluation of the robustness of the approach in the presence of non-defect related process disturbances.

If successful, real-time weld defect detection would substantially reduce the total cost of friction stir welding by reducing or eliminating the need for costly post-process inspection work. In addition, the development and validation of process and defect formation models will improve our understanding of the complex solid-state friction stir welding process. The resulting reduction in cost and increase in process understanding would help accelerate its adoption as a joining process - providing the substantial economic, environmental, and energy conservation advantages that wide-spread adoption of friction stir welding and friction stir processing would bring. Finally, the project will have a strong training and mentoring focus by providing an integrated educational and research environment for graduate and undergraduate student researchers - including those in underrepresented groups through established University fellowship programs.

ProgramReference.Text: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

POR.DRECONTENT:
This National Science Foundation grant was used to conduct fundamental scientific research on detecting defects, such as voids, that are formed during the solid-state material joining process known as friction stir welding. Friction stir welds were created in aluminum alloys under a wide range of operating conditions. Some of these operating conditions resulted in fully-dense welds without any voids. Other operating conditions were chosen because they produced friction stir welds with voids, which are defects that can significantly reduce the strength of the joint. The forces and force variations during friction stir welding were measured for all to the tests that were conducted. In addition, X-ray imaging of the welds was used to measure the size and distribution of any voids left by the welding process. Analysis of the force and void data was used to develop a method for predicting voids based only on force measurements. This method does two things: (1) it identifies if voids are present, and (2) if voids are present it estimates their total size. This force-based method for detecting the creation of voids in friction stir welds was developed for and tested on quarter-inch-thick butt welds of aluminum alloy 6061-T6. Preliminary data that shows that other aluminum alloys (3000-series and 7000-series aluminum) produces force signals that look different friction stir welds with voids versus those without voids. Hence, the general approach developed for detecting defects in aluminum alloy 6061-T6 during friction stir welding should be applicable to other aluminum alloys, with some adjustments. The research conducted for this grant has also lead to an increased understanding of a fundamental phenomenon present in all friction stir welds, which is believed to play an important role in the formation of voids. Based on data collected during this research, it is hypothesized that a cavity is formed behind the friction stir tool and filled during every rotation of the tool. There is strong evidence to suggest that this occurs during every friction stir welding process, whether the process leaves voids in the resultant weld or not. It is believed that the periodic formation and filling of this cavity, is a natural part of the friction stir welding process. This means that friction stir welding conditions that result in voids do not allow for complete filling of the cavity that is formed during each rotation of the tool.

 

This research has developed a new non-destructive defect detection method that can be applied to friction stir welding. The method only requires that the process forces be measured during welding. The friction stir welding forces can be measured in real-time and the method is simple enough to perform its calculations in real-time. This means that the method could be used in real-time and alert the machine operator that the welding process is leaving behind voids in the joint. This information can be used to adjust the process to improve weld quality and the region of weld where defects were detected can be marked for further inspection. Only having to inspect lengths of weld where a defect has been detected will reduce the cost of post-process inspection work. The improved understanding of the friction stir welding process will help accelerate its adoption as a joining process - providing substantial economic and energy saving advantages that this processes offers. The researchers have also transferred their knowledge of friction stir welding aluminum alloys to a Wisconsin company that is implementing this process for the first time. In addition, this project has provided an integrated educational and research environment that has helped train three bachelor’s degree students, three master’s degree students, five doctoral degree students, and one postdoctoral researcher. 

 


Last Modified: 11/27/2017
Modified by: Frank E Pfefferkorn
